title: Add MFA exclusions callout to CA slides
description:
## Overview

The outline explicitly lists "MFA exclusions" as part of the CA Detection example (Section 4c), but current slides don't mention it.

## What to Add

Enhance slide 011 or 012 with a callout showing:

- **Frame:** "MFA exclusion = skeleton key to your tenant"
- **What attackers do:**
  1. Emergency exclusion - add backdoor user to MFA bypass
  2. Legacy auth backdoor - enable protocols that skip MFA
  3. Trusted location expansion - attacker's IP becomes "trusted"
- **Detection triggers:** User added to exclusion, legacy auth enabled, named location modified

## Where It Fits

Within existing CA section (slides 011-013), not a new slide.

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] MFA exclusions explicitly mentioned in slide 011 or 012
- [ ] At least one concrete attack scenario shown
- [ ] Ties back to "why this matters" for MSPs

- Light: #F79D9D, #F9BDBD
- Dark: #792E2E, #3C1717

### Ops Indigo (Contrast/Backgrounds - 15% usage)

- Light: #968EB5, #BAB3CF
- Dark: #282242, #141121

### Cloud Gray (Neutral - 20% usage)

## Typography (from PDF page 8-9)

### Goldplay Bold
- Use: Title, Button, Link
- Note: Premium font - need files or use Montserrat Bold fallback

### Montserrat (Google Fonts)
- Black (900): Lead/subtitles
- Medium/Regular (500/400): Paragraph, body text
- Light (300): Lighter body text
- URL: https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Montserrat

## Design Rules (from PDF)
- Buttons: Pill-shaped with maximum border radius
- Rounded corners: 12.5% radius relative to object height
- Grid: 9-column system
- Stewart mascot: Can use outline form (stroke = 2.5% of height)

## Text/Background Pairings (WCAG compliant)
- Bot Teal bg → Dark teal text (#005655)
- Trigger Amber bg → Dark brown text
- Alert Coral bg → Dark text
- Cloud Gray bg → Bot Teal text (#1EAFAF)
- Ops Indigo bg → White text

1. Add Montserrat via Google Fonts in index.html
2. Update /src/config/colors.js with Rewst palette
3. Update /src/config/themes.js - create Rewst theme
4. Update /src/config/typography.js with Montserrat stack
5. Update tailwind.config.js with custom colors

7. Test all slides for visual consistency

Source: _Rewst_VisualGuidelines.pdf

title: Add slides: AI scenarios in tabletop exercises
description:
Add 1-2 slides explaining why organizations should incorporate AI-specific scenarios into tabletop exercises.

## Why Traditional Tabletops Miss AI Threats
- Phishing has grammar tells → AI phishing is perfect
- Voice verification works → Deepfakes defeat call-back verification
- Data stays where you put it → Shadow AI creates invisible exfiltration
- Incident response has clear IOCs → AI attacks may leave no forensic artifacts
- Humans review before action → Agentic AI acts autonomously

## Key Scenarios to Include
1. Shadow AI / unauthorized AI usage with client data
2. AI-generated phishing and deepfake voice calls
3. Prompt injection against customer-facing AI
4. AI API key exposure and cost explosion attacks
5. Agentic AI exploitation (AI with tool access being manipulated)

## Educational Points
- AI incidents are non-deterministic (cannot reproduce the bug)
- Most AI incidents are system incidents, not model incidents
- Teams need to understand context windows, hallucination, confidence vs correctness
- Dispel misconception that we can just roll back the model

## Slide Content Ideas
- Title: Is Your Tabletop Ready for AI?
- Show gap analysis table: Traditional Assumption vs AI Reality
- Include 2-3 specific scenario examples
- End with facilitator questions teams should be asking

Research provided by ai-threat-researcher and ai-concepts-teacher agents.

title: Add Endpoint Protection Testing section (Section 6)
description:
## Overview

The session outline promises "safely test endpoint detection" but the current presentation has no dedicated content for this. This is a major gap that needs to be filled before the February 4th session.

## What We're Adding

### New Slides (insert after Break - slide 017)

1. **"Safe Endpoint Testing" framing slide**
   - What "safe" means in MSP context
   - Scoped targets (test ring / lab)
   - Two-tier approach: production-safe vs lab-fidelity
   - Expected alerts + rollback/cleanup

2. **"What Attackers Check First" slide**
   - ASR rules disabled/audit mode
   - AV exclusions on user-writable paths
   - Local admin sprawl
   - PowerShell logging gaps

3. **"Endpoint Validation Sandwich" slide**
   - Maps the guardrail pattern to endpoint testing
   - Deterministic checks → AI explains gaps → Human approves fix

### Live Demo (~12 min)

| Demo | Method | Shows |
|------|--------|-------|
| ASR Rules Gap | `Get-MpPreference` | Disabled LSASS protection |
| AV Exclusion Audit | `Get-MpPreference \| Select Exclusion*` | Dangerous paths excluded |
| Atomic Red Team | `Invoke-AtomicTest T1003.001` | Detection fires (or doesn't) |
| Local Admin Sprawl | `Get-LocalGroupMember` | Shared admin = lateral movement |
| PowerShell Logging | Registry check | Invisible attacks if disabled |

### Demo Environment

- 2-3 local VMs (one "good config," one "bad config")
- Vendor-neutral (no Intune dependency)
- Works with any RMM tool

## Key Design Decisions

1. **Vendor-neutral** - PowerShell checks work on any Windows endpoint
2. **Honest about AI** - "AI is not the sensor. Your EDR + config baselines are the sensors."
3. **Two-tier testing** - Built-in safe tests for production, Atomic for lab
4. **MSP framing** - "Here's what to check, here's how to automate across your fleet"

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] "Safe Endpoint Testing" framing slide created
- [ ] "What Attackers Check First" slide created
- [ ] "Endpoint Validation Sandwich" slide created
- [ ] Demo scripts tested on local VMs
- [ ] Pre-recorded backup video of alerts firing
- [ ] Slide deck renumbered appropriately

## Related Gaps (separate beads)

- MFA exclusions callout in CA slides
- Network segmentation slide
- AI risk dynamics explicit framing
